I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based  grant  to  the  Republic  of  Kiribati  for  subprogram  2  of  the  Strengthening  Economic 
Management Reform Program.1 
 
  The program aims to strengthen Kiribati’s economic management and create a more 
stable macroeconomic framework. This is the second subprogram under the programmatic 
approach, which will build on current government-led reforms supported by a multi-partner policy 
action matrix.2 Its focus improved (i) management of public finances, assets, and liabilities; and 
(ii) economic environment for the private sector, aligns with the Kiribati Development Plan (KDP) 
for 2016–2019 and Kiribati Vision 20 (KV20).3 Subprogram 2 aligns with the operational priority 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of strengthening governance and institutional capacity 
under Strategy 2030.4 
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
  Development  challenges.  One  of  the  most  remote  and  geographically  dispersed 
countries in the world, Kiribati comprises 33 islands spread over 5 million square kilometers of 
ocean. Kiribati is classified as a fragile and conflicted affected situation, and this fragility and the 
limited government capacity has guided the scope of this program.5 The capital, Tarawa, is about 
4,000 kilometers from the major trade markets of Australia, Hawaii, and New Zealand. The 
extreme remoteness and large dispersion create significant hurdles to service delivery. Kiribati’s 
low-lying atolls rise by an average of 1.8 meters above sea level and are therefore at the forefront 
of climate change. Thus the country is vulnerable to external shocks because of its geographic 
characteristics; high exposure to the negative effects of climate change; high dependence on 
imports; and heavy reliance on income from external sources such as investment income from its 
sovereign wealth fund, the Revenue Equalization Reserve Fund (RERF).  
 
  The government is the largest employer but its capacity, including that of central ministries, 
is hampered by limited skills in public finance, accounting, economic assessment, and project 
management. Outdated and ineffective information technology systems worsen these capacity 
constraints. As a result there is limited publicly available information on the government’s fiscal 
strategy, cash management and management of the RERF have not been as effective as would 
be  ideal,  and  potential  economies  from  centralized  and  professionally  managed  public 
procurement are missed. The government also relies heavily on development partner financing 
and imported technical capacity for major project implementation. Like many Pacific countries, 
Kiribati has been struggling with the build-and-rebuild cycle of infrastructure provision, and found

because small and remote populations prove costly to serve. 
 
  Private sector development has been constrained by high business, investment, and 
connectivity costs. The public sector plays a dominant role in the economy, absorbing available 
skilled staff and crowding out private initiatives through state-owned enterprises (SOEs) that 
operate in potentially competitive sectors.6 Further divestment and outsourcing of SOE activities 
to the private sector is required to encourage private sector-led growth.7 An effective program of 
asset maintenance offers another opportunity for private sector development while at the same 
time ensuring that new public assets are maintained for future effective use. Without independent 
monetary and exchange rate policies—Kiribati has adopted the Australian dollar, and the leverage 
of banking regulation and interest rate policy is limited—the government relies on fiscal policy to 
manage the impact of shocks and stimulate inclusive growth. The International Monetary Fund 
(IMF) considers Kiribati to be at high risk of debt distress; its baseline scenario shows debt 
indicators to be breached given weak growth prospects and the long-term cost of climate change 
(footnote 6). The reforms supported by this program aim to strengthen the fiscal environment and 
boost growth to build resilience to shocks. 
 
  Recent economic and fiscal performance. Economic performance has been strong 
recently: despite intrinsic challenges, gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 3% yearly during 
2011–2017, buoyed by revenues from fishing licenses and investments by development partners 
in roads, waste management, and sanitation. The current account relies heavily on imported 
goods and is constrained in terms of exports—exports of mostly copra and fish totaled $14 million 
in  2016—but  is  typically  in  surplus  because  of  fishing  license  fees,  RERF  income,  and 
remittances. Inflation has remained low (Table 1). 
 
  Fishing license revenue in 2016–2017 exceeded A$150 million, or 60% of GDP, yearly.8 
While this is a decline from the peak in 2015 (A$207 million), fishing license revenue remains a 
significant source of income; the A$130 million in projected revenue for 2018 was achieved by 
October. Tax revenue during 2011–2016 stagnated at 14%–16% of GDP, though a strong focus 
on revenue administration and collection of arrears underpinned a rise in tax revenue in 2017. 
After the 2016 election of a government with a policy platform focused on improving the quality of 
life in the outer islands, public expenditure rose, driven by large infrastructure projects financed 
by development partners, and increases in health and education spending. The copra subsidy 
was raised from A$8.0 million in 2015 to A$22.8 million in 2016, to A$30.6 million in 2017 because 
it is seen as a means for people to remain on the outer islands and for the government to 
redistribute rising resource wealth.9 Stagnating wages since 2011 caused social pressures to 
build, and in 2018 salaries were adjusted by 21% in real terms. Higher expenditure and lower 
fishing revenue contributed to lowering the fiscal surplus from the equivalent of 42.6% of GDP in 
2015 to 4.1% of GDP in 2016, and reverting it to a deficit of 9.2% of GDP in 2017 (Table 1).10 A

  Medium-term fiscal path. ADB forecasts growth to remain at 2.3% in 2018 and 2019, but 
declining fishing license revenues are expected to result in a fiscal deficit of 7.3% of GDP in 2018 
and 10.9% of GDP in 2019. The recent sustained increases in RERF investment income mean 
that the fund has achieved the A$1 billion level ahead of its 2020 target; given this growth, RERF 
deposits in 2015 and 2016 were not continued in 2017 or 2018. A backlog of expenditure demands 
(e.g., wages, copra subsidies, transportation assets) remains. The government recognizes that 
the volatility of fishing revenues, severe infrastructure deficits (particularly on the outer islands), 
limited capacity to take on new debt, and the negative effects of climate change mean that it must 
remain vigilant and continue efforts to build fiscal buffers and secure support from development 
partners for project and policy financing. Future budget decisions will need to account for a 
prudent assessment of Kiribati’s spending goals and revenue projections and the management 
targets of the RERF. Maintaining a sustainable budget position in the medium term will be central 
to this effort, based on fishing revenue projections that allow the government to protect its public 
expenditure programs from potential revenue volatility, complemented by an appropriately sized 
cash reserve to deal with external shocks.

B.  Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 
 
  Government reform priorities. Approved in 2018, KV20 is Kiribati’s first long-term 
development planning framework. It seeks to maximize the development benefits from fisheries 
and tourism as key productive sectors, and strategies include (i) promoting inclusive trade and

4 
the private sector for sustainable development, and (ii) undertaking reforms to improve the quality 
and efficiency of public service and service delivery. The KDP is the implementing mechanism 
that will be used to execute KV20 objectives, and it sets out the overarching objective of a more 
stable macroeconomic framework (footnote 2). 
 
  Government reform progress. The KDP has provided guidance to reform through its key 
priority areas of human resource development, economic growth and poverty reduction, health, 
environment, governance, and infrastructure. Policy actions are designed to support these key 
priority areas along with developing a sustainable macroeconomic environment to ensure long-
term sustainability. 
 
  Technical assistance (TA), policy dialogue, and policy-based financing from ADB and 
other development partners have helped the government prioritize, appropriately sequence, and 
implement reforms focused on improving weak economic management, containing unsustainable 
RERF drawdowns, managing high levels of non-concessional debt and stopping uncoordinated 
borrowing by ministries made without approval from the Ministry of Finance and Economic 
Development (MFED), improving poorly performing SOEs, and building capacity to improve the 
weak management of fisheries revenues.11 
 
  Development partner coordination. The Economic Reform Taskforce (ERT), chaired by 
the secretary to the cabinet, is the main forum for consultation and coordination between the 
government and development partners on the implementation of policy action reforms.12 The ERT 
comprises representatives from the MFED; implementing agencies such as the Ministry of 
Fisheries and Marine Resources Development; the Ministry of Information, Communication, 
Transport, and Tourism Development; and development partners. The ERT meetings, held during 
joint missions by all four development partner members, provide a forum for facilitating dialogue, 
monitoring progress, and coordinating TA. Other avenues for coordination include the annual IMF 
Article IV consultations and the biennial Development Partners Forum. 
 
  ADB collaborated closely with the World Bank and the governments of Australia and New 
Zealand in preparing this program, which is underpinned by a joint government-led policy matrix 
monitored by the ERT.13 This, along with complementary measures such as joint missions, 
reduces transaction costs for the government while increasing the policy impact. ADB and the 
World Bank consulted the IMF and its Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre to coordinate 
policy advice and TA, particularly in fisheries revenue and public finance management (PFM). As 
part of ADB’s differentiated approach to small island developing states and FCAS highlighted in 
Strategy 2030 (foonote 3), considerable TA is being provided to Kiribati in coordination with 
development  partners  to  facilitate  reform  implementation,  as  specifically  identified  in  the 
discussion of reform areas below. 
 
  Policy  actions.  The  KDP  provides  the  framework  from  which  policy  actions  were 
developed (para. 9). The overall development objective of the program is to achieve a stable

5 
macroeconomic  framework.  The  effect  of  the  reform  will  be  improved  overall  economic 
management. The program has two reform areas supported across the two subprograms and 
subprogram 2 contains nine policy actions (Appendix 4). The government completed all nine 
actions for subprogram 2. Some indicative actions identified during the processing of subprogram 
1 have required modification or removal to reflect changing circumstances and significant capacity 
constraints, however all adjustments have been made while ensuring a qualitatively strong 
program  processing  government’s  medium  term  objective. 14  A  post-program  monitoring 
framework was developed and agreed with the government to support progress towards these 
medium term objectives, and guide policy dialogue and TA to further the program objectives 
beyond its completion date. The ERT will monitor and report on framework implementation to the 
MFED and development partners, including ADB. Framework implementation will be supported 
by coordinated technical assistance from all partners, and progress within the framework will 
guide the development of future policy-based operations by development partners. 
 
  Reform area 1: Management of public finances, assets, and liabilities improved. 
These reforms will contribute to wider improvements in the maintenance of fiscal sustainability, 
the containment of fiscal risks, and overall improvement to PFM practices. 
 
  The government completed, and the cabinet endorsed, the evaluation and selection of an 
RERF custodian. The RERF is Kiribati’s most significant financial asset; it was designed so its 
income  provides  additional  budget  financing  given  the  domestic  revenue  constraints.  The 
government has set out the policy intent to ensure sound RERF management. Under subprogram 
1, the government completed a review of its RERF custodial arrangements to make sure that the 
services of the current provider remain competitive with current market practice and benchmarks; 
the review recommended competitive selection of a new custodian. The RERF Investment 
Committee selected a preferred service provider and undertook due diligence on this provider, 
and the cabinet endorsed the selection. The indicative action envisaged that the contract between 
the government and the custodian would be signed by now but this has not yet happened because 
of extended commercial negotiations that are outside the government’s direct control. 
 
  The cabinet endorsed a set of objectives for managing the RERF designed to achieve the 
government’s target of reaching fund assets of A$1 billion by 2020. Government efforts moved 
beyond  the  strengthened  custodial  arrangement  discussed  in  para.  16  to  improve  RERF 
governance by approving a set of objectives to achieve a nominal value of A$1 billion by 2020.15 
The RERF objectives are to (i) enable the government to become self-sufficient in its ability to 
finance future development projects, (ii) manage the fund in a way that maximizes the return 
benefits from long-term investing without incurring undue risk, and (iii) manage the fund for future 
sustainability by making sure that the real long-term value of the assets is maintained. This 
additional action by government reflects its commitment to both improved governance of the 
RERF, and the broader medium term objective of strengthened management of all government 
assets. 
 
  The government further improved its management of contingent liabilities. While Kiribati 
has limited external debt,16 the implementation of a public sector debt database in subprogram 1 
enabled the government to better monitor all debt, including contingent liabilities such as small 
debts incurred in SOE daily operations. Elsewhere in the Pacific, SOEs have on occasions 
entered into debt, for which government was liable, without requisite approvals – Kiribati’s close 
monitoring of debt acts to minimize the risk of this occurring. Strong adherence to process and

based on recommendations from the public expenditure and financial accountability framework assessment, and two 
underwent some wording changes. 
15 The World Bank provided support for this task and the objectives are alined with best practices.

6 
capability strengthening kept this up to date through 2018 allowing for close monitoring of the 
government’s overall debt position. The 2017 financial statements of the five major SOEs—Air 
Kiribati Limited, Development Bank of Kiribati, Kiribati Oil Company Ltd, Kiribati Ports Authority, 
and the Public Utilities Board—and of the Kiribati Provident Fund were completed and submitted 
to the Kiribati National Audit Office for audit. This is a significant and sustained turnaround from 
the situation just a few years ago where  such audits were many years behind and the true 
financial positions of these SOEs were unknown. Better-managed contingent liabilities were a key 
area of reform to support fiscal stability, and the government allocated the necessary resources 
to sustain this activity. 
 
  Public finance management. The government initiated a comprehensive report on the 
shortcomings of its financial management information system (FMIS) although the start was 
delayed due to delays in donor financing. An indicative action proposed for subprogram 2 was 
removed from the matrix because financing for this work was delayed, and the complex analysis 
in the report requires more time to ensure a quality product. This report will be finalized in late 
2018 and is expected to lead to a request-for-proposal process to enable the improvement or 
replacement of the FMIS, for which the government has already set aside funding, a strong 
demonstration  of  its  intent  to  progress  this  work.  The  post-program  monitoring  framework 
highlights the next steps in this process. 
 
  Government has undertaken additional actions to strengthen public financial management 
– reflected as two new actions in subprogram 2. First, while the government regularly develops a 
comprehensive  annual  fiscal  strategy,  it  has  never  made  this  public.  To  improve  budget 
transparency, the government published the fiscal strategy and committed to annual publication 
of its strategy. The content of the strategy and its publication are consistent with best practice and 
respond  directly  to  the  IMF’s  recommendations  from  its  public  expenditure  and  financial 
accountability framework assessment. 
 
  Second, a commitment to more robust cash management, as outlined in the fiscal 
strategy, was realized through the development of a cash management policy and its approval by 
the cabinet. The implementation of the policy resulted in the transfer of cash balances from zero-
interest accounts into an interest-bearing account. This will bring cash in these accounts from 
about 7 months of recurrent budget down to 3 months, as suggested by the IMF. A planned review 
of the number and role of special funds accounts will further improve the management of cash 
reserves.17 
 
  Community  service  obligations.  As  an  important  budgetary  item  for  SOEs,  the 
government published SOE funding guidelines on its website to make clear the purpose of funding 
and how applications can be made. This has strengthened the direct link between the cost of 
providing the non-commercial community service and the amount transferred through the budget. 
This has eliminated the need for regular cash injections to bring the SOEs back into a sound 
financial position. 
 
  State-owned  enterprises.  In  2017,  under  subprogram  1,  the  cabinet  approved  a 
concession-plus-lease arrangement for the government-owned Captain Cook Hotel on Kiritimati 
island. Based on feedback from the Attorney General regarding irregularities, negotiation with the 
preferred bidder was terminated and the procurement process restarted. That this irregularity was 
detected  and  acted  upon,  in  line  with  set  procedures,  should  be  considered  a  successful 
demonstration of the effectiveness of the government reform processes. Progress has since been 
good, and the cabinet approved a preferred bidder for negotiation to commence. The contract is 
not expected to be finalized until late 2018 or early 2019, so this indicative action was removed 
                                                
17 The government estimated that the excess cash holding could be costing it as much as A$1.8 million per year in 
forgone interest.

7 
from the matrix. However, the completion of this contract award is reflected in the post-program 
monitoring framework.18 
 
  Procurement. In 2017, the cabinet approved the Kiribati Public Procurement Reform 
Program  as  a  first  step  to  overhaul  outdated  and  incomplete  procurement  processes  and 
governance. This was included as a new action to reflect the steps toward reform taken in 2018 
to establish a Central Procurement Office and hire a chief procurement officer and a procurement 
officer, ensuring equal opportunity employment. With TA provided by ADB and cofinanced by the 
Government of New Zealand, these officers will develop all policies and processes for centralized 
procurement. This action is reflected in the policy matrix in recognition that a centralized unit with 
dedicated staff will ensure an immediate focus on procurement, and the planned reforms will 
establish strong regulations and legislation to support transparent and efficient procurement. 
 
  Reform area 2: Environment for the private sector improved. Since growth led by the 
private sector is important for the government, the program supports the following reforms: 
 
(i)  Access  to  basic  utilities.  The  government  approved  water  tariffs  to  be 
implemented at pilot sites in Tarawa. Access to reliable and responsibly costed 
electricity and water is vital to encourage the growth of the private sector. After the 
successful introduction of electricity tariffs in 2017 the government approved water 
tariffs in 2018. Two pilot sites received, for the first time, piped water that is 
available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week through a pressurized system; services 
are being charged at the set tariffs. Implementation will be analyzed with a view to 
further rollouts in parallel with 24/7 water availability across Tarawa. The tariffs are 
aligned to cost recovery based on cost plus community service obligation, so the 
setting and collection of tariffs underpin the provision of a reliable water service. 
 
(ii)  Assets. The government made a commitment to the development of an asset 
registry  and  asset  management  plan.  A  statement  of  commitment  to  asset 
management and maintenance was included in the fiscal strategy for the 2019 
budget. The management plan for all major government-owned assets, originally 
planned  for  2018  in  the  indicative  actions,  was  delayed  because  of  the 
unavailability of development partner support, but is expected to be underway in 
early  2019.  The  completion  of  the  plan  is  in  the  post-program  monitoring 
framework and will be tracked by the ERT. Asset management and maintenance 
budgets will provide private sector opportunities for contracts. 
 
(iii)  Public–private partnership concessions. In 2017, the government terminated 
the existing concession agreement and assigned the management of the Otintaai 
Hotel to the Kiribati Provident Fund. The fund has since begun civil works to make 
the hotel commercially viable and hired a firm to complete a feasibility study, which 
is expected to be finalized in early 2019. As a result the indicative action regarding 
the contracting out of the Otintaii is now a medium term government objective, the 
short term focus being on completion of the feasibility study to allow the information 
needed for planning the future of the hotel to be available. There are no actions 
aorund the Otintaii Hotel, rather progress on having Government step back from 
the operation of the hotel will be monitored through the post program monitoring 
framework.   
 
  ADB’s value addition. ADB has played a critical role in (i) identifying priority SOE, PFM, 
and business environment reforms to support the government’s reform agenda;(ii) enhancing 
 
development coordination by coordinating and collaborating with other development partner 
                                                
18 The post-program management framework is in the policy matrix in Appendix 4.

8 
initiatives; and (iii) providing TA for capacity building and reform implementation, particularly SOE 
reform.19 Given the government's limited administrative capacity, the aim to stem significant 
deterioration in infrastructure assets and improve service delivery to the outer islands would have 
been difficult and costly to realize without ADB's technical, strategic, and financial support. This 
support aligns with the KDP and is consistent with the Pacific Approach, 2016–2020 and its focus 
on reducing the cost of doing business and providing social services, managing risks from natural 
and economic shocks, and enabling value creation by supporting private sector growth and 
investment.20 Future ADB support will continue to make the implementation of reforms (SOE and 
procurement) easier. Learning from subprogram 1 and other policy-based lending in the Pacific, 
subprogram 2 focuses on supporting the stated priorities of the government, breaking reform 
areas into achievable steps, and providing needed support for the government to follow these 
through to the end. 
 
C.  Impacts of the Reform 
 
  The implementation of the policy actions across the two subprograms contributed to the 
improvement of Kiribati’s economic management and the development of a much stronger 
macroeconomic framework. The actions under the first reform area (on management of public 
finances, assets, and liabilities) includes actions to strengthen the management of Kiribati’s 
sovereign wealth fund, improve cash management, auditing of SOEs, and address weaknesses 
in  the  public  investment  cycle,  including  procurement.  These  actions  should  contribute  to 
enhancing  the  management  of  financial  assets,  the  quality  of  public  spending,  and  the 
performance of SOEs. Improvement in timeliness and quality of accounting and auditing of SOEs 
will strengthen governance, transparency and accountability, which is in turn expected to improve 
their  performance  and  service  delivery  and  help  avoid  unsustainable  borrowing,  reduce 
contingent liabilities, create more room for private investment, and improve reliability, efficiency, 
and affordability of public services. Critical areas of work begun during the program will continue, 
including the work toward an improved FMIS and the development of an asset management and 
maintenance culture. These and related actions have improved the ability of the MFED to manage 
and report on the economy. Increased macroeconomic resilience resulting from program reforms 
will reduce the negative impact of external shocks, including on growth and service delivery. 
Furthermore, the public sector is a substantial employer of women, and has been effective in 
ensuring women have access to high level positions – in 2017 women held 54% of Secretary of 
Ministry positions (footnote 6). This equal opportunity approach to recruitment saw women 
employed for both the new procurement positions created. 
 
  The second reform area, on improving the environment for the private sector, includes 
actions to expand access to safe drinking water in a sustainable manner and support asset 
maintenance. Improvements in the delivery of basic water services have an impact on the most 
vulnerable segment of Kiribati's society and will disproportionately benefit women and girls: 
directly by reducing time spent fetching water for washing and cleaning, and indirectly through 
better health outcomes since the prevalence of diarrhea and dysentery is higher among girls than 
boys, and also because I-Kiribati women are mainly responsible for caring for sick children. It is 
notable that 23% of households are headed by women.21 
 
                                                
19 ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Kiribati for Enhancing Economic Competitiveness through State-
Owned Enterprise Reform. Manila.  
20 ADB. 2017. Pacific Approach, 2016–2020. Manila. 
21 Government  of  Kiribati,  National  Statistics  Office.  2018.  Kiribati  Gender  Statiscs  Abstract,  2017.  Tarawa. 
http://www.mfed.gov.ki/sites/default/files/Kiribati_2017_Gender_Statistics_Abstract%20FINAL.pdf.

9 
D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
 
  The government has requested a grant not exceeding $2.5 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources (Asian Development Fund) to help finance the program. The grant will (i) help 
bridge the financing gap for the 2018 fiscal year and (ii) incentivize timely implementation of the 
policy reform actions needed to move toward fiscal sustainability in the long term. The government 
forecasts its financing requirements to be $13.7 million in 2018 (7.3% of GDP) and $21.4 million 
in 2019 (10.9% of GDP). 
 
  Budget  support  will  help  insulate  public  spending  from  potential  volatility  in  fishing 
revenues, minimize drawdowns from the RERF and enable its growth, and allow the government 
to move toward structurally balanced budgets in the medium term. ADB, the governments of 
Australia and New Zealand, and the World Bank jointly support the implementation of these 
reforms, with collaborative cofinancing of $0.36 million (Australia), $2.00 million (New Zealand), 
and $5.00 million (World Bank). Total policy financing of $9.86 million will help finance 71% of the 
recurrent fiscal deficit. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
  The program is expected to be implemented over 29 months from November 2016 to 
December 2018. The implementation period for subprogram 2 is January 2018 to December 
2018. The MFED, as executing agency, provided oversight of the implementation of agreed policy 
actions and will be responsible for program administration, disbursements, and maintenance of 
all records. The implementing agencies were the MFED and the Ministry of Infrastructure and 
Sustainable  Energy.  ADB  and  other  partners  will  continue  to  assist  the  government  in 
accomplishing the policy actions. ADB will disburse the grant proceeds following ADB’s Loan 
Disbursement Handbook (2017, as amended from time to time). ADB will undertake progress 
monitoring through the joint ERT. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
  Safeguards. The  program  is  classified  category  C for the  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous peoples. ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department has reviewed the environmental and social implications of the program outputs and 
actions, and no activity will result in or lead to any physical works or infrastructure. The program 
will therefore not cause any involuntary resettlement and environmental impacts. No distinct and 
vulnerable groups of indigenous peoples will be affected. 
 
  The focus on improving the management of public finances, assets, and liabilities along 
with strong SOE reform will benefit the poor and vulnerable in Kiribati directly by improving public 
services; and indirectly by enabling the government to better develop and implement its budget, 
inclusive of social programs. Improved financial management can free up resources that will allow 
the government to better respond to external shocks, increase allocations to social sectors, and 
indirectly enable private sector job creation. 
 
  Governance. Promoting good governance is a key national priority. The 2010 Public 
Financial Management Performance Report identified relative strengths in Kiribati’s PFM. The 
report also highlighted weaknesses, such as in oversight of aggregate fiscal risk from other public 
sector entities; multiyear perspective in fiscal planning; recording and management of cash 
balances, debt, and guarantees; and competition, value for money, and controls in procurement.22 
Through the reforms under subprograms 1 and 2, the government made steady progress in 
                                                
22 Government of Kiribati. Public Financial Management Performance Report. Unpublished; and Government of Kiribati. 
Public Financial Management (PFM) Reform Plan, 2011–2014. Unpublished.

10 
meeting these needs (para. 8). It also strengthened expenditure controls with better accounting 
systems. Kiribati’s annual budget is publicly available on the government’s website.

the risk assessment and risk management plan.23

  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed

IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
  The government and the MFED have assured ADB that implementation of the program 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the grant agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
grant not exceeding $2,500,000 to the Republic of Kiribati from ADB’s Special Funds resources 
(Asian  Development  Fund) for  subprogram  2 of the  Strengthening  Economic  Management 
Reform Program, on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth 
in the draft grant agreement presented to the Board.

metadata.Subject:
The program aims to strengthen Kiribati’s economic management and create a more stable macroeconomic framework. This is the second subprogram under the programmatic approach, which will build on current government-led reforms supported by a multi-partner policyaction matrix.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated November 2018 is provided for the ADB project 47322-002 in Kiribati.
